Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Subsampling Methods in Statistical Modeling of Ultra-Large Sample Geophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Remote sensing of the Earth's deep interior is challenging. Direct sampling of the Earth's deep interior is impossible due to the extreme pressures and temperatures. Our knowledge of the Earth?s deep interior is thus pieced together from a range of surface observations. Among surface observations, seismic waves emitted by earthquakes are effective probes of the Earth?s deep interior and are relatively inexpensively recorded by networks of seismographs at the Earth's surface. Unprecedented volumes of seismic data brought by dense global seismograph networks offer researchers both opportunities and challenges to explore the Earth?s deep interior. The key challenge is that directly applying statistical methods to this ultra-large sample seismic data using current computing resources is prohibitive. To facilitate geophysical discoveries that can enhance our understanding of the Earth?s deep interior using current computing resources, the investigator proposes a family of novel statistical methods under a subsampling framework. The proposed methods provide an opportunity to study various distinct statistical problems, such as function estimation and variable selection, in a unified framework. The investigator will establish asymptotic and finite sample theory to investigate the approximation accuracy and consistency of the proposed methods.

How to analyze ultra-large sample data creates a significant challenge in almost all fields of science and engineering. Scientists and engineers develop various solutions to tackle the problem, such as developing cloud computing for aggregating a wide range of computing resources and building powerful supercomputers. However, the high cost of these solutions creates an extraordinary budget barrier for researchers. The proposed subsampling methods provide alternative methods to surmount this challenge. The theory to be established will benefit a wide spectrum of research in science and engineering. They will offer a unique educational experience for both undergraduate and graduate students to participate in cutting-edge statistical and interdisciplinary research and inspire new lines of researches in three distinct fields: statistics, geophysics, and computational biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
(1) Accurate identification of differentially expressed (DE) genes in time course RNA-Seq data is crucial for understanding the dynamics of the transcriptional regulatory network. However, most of the available methods treat gene expressions at different time points as replicates and test the significance of the mean expression difference between treatments or conditions irrespective of time, which raises the difficulty to identify many DE genes with different profiles across time. We aim to identify DE genes in time course RNA-Seq data through a negative binomial mixed-effect model (NBMM).
In time course RNA-Seq experiments, the short read counts cannot be adequately modeled by independent Gaussian distribution. We extend the nonparametric model and penalized likelihood method to develop a negative binomial mixed-effect model (NBMM) for modeling time course RNA-Seq data. Once the model is fitted to the exon level read counts data, we identify NPDE and PDE genes by testing the significance of the interaction and main effects.We evaluated the performance of the proposed method by carrying out extensive analysis on simulated datasets under three settings: linear pattern, exponential pattern and cyclic pattern. The performance of NBMM is pretty well for all settings compared with other existing methods.Then we apply an RNA-Seq simulator to simulate RNA-Seq experiments. The NBMM method detected all NPDE genes enriched gene sets, whereas the GSA method did not identify any significant gene sets.We also do real data analysis. By applying the NBMM to study the development of Drosophila melanogaster. The result shows that gene sets detected by the NBMM are more biologically relevant to development.

(2) Advances in streaming data acquisition technology bring challenges in analyzing large volumes of streaming data. Due to the competent estimation accuracy and low computation cost, sampling method has been regarded as a powerful tool for analyzing large sample data. However, sampling method and its statistical properties for streaming data, especially streaming time series data, are not well studied. We want to apply a novel leverage-based sequential sampling algorithm to streaming time series data which follows an autoregressive (AR) model.
We apply the sequential leveraging sampling method for streaming AR(p) series and establish theoretical results.We work out some simulation studies to illustrate the validity of the asymptotic normality result and superior performance of leverage-based sequential sampling.We then apply sequential leveraging sampling method to the seismic data. Our method shows a better performance than uniform sampling. We also apply the sequential leveraging method to the Internet traffic data and we show that as a streaming data analysis tool, our sequential leveraging method is flexible enough to capture the local change of underlying streaming data.

(3) Transposable elements (TEs) are a feature of almost all eukaryotic genomes. It will present a considerable danger to genome integrity and species survival if left unchecked. Therefore, organisms have evolved robust pathways to silence the expression of transposable elements and to restrict their mobility, among which DNA and chromatin modification and small RNA-mediated silencing are ancient and conserved mechanisms. Transcription and mobility of TEs are actively suppressed by the two-step piRNA/22G-RNA coTGS system in C.elegans. We aim to gain further insight into coTGS mechanisms in animals. Specifically, we want to identify protein interactors of the germline Argonaute HRDE-1in C. elegans.
We first produce whole-cell protein extracts from wild-type young adult C. elegans grown on “heavy” isotopes and hrde-1(tm1200) mutant animals grown on “light” isotopes. We then choose the young adult stage as the germline. Next, We immunoprecipitate a 1:1 mix of protein extracts of both genotypes and focused on 53 proteins with human orthologs. Finally, we use the STRING database to identify known protein complexes between factors.Our SILAC based HRDE-1 proteomics identify a set of conserved proteins that might bridge sRNA pathways, RNA processing, and TE silencing.Of the candidate HRDE-1 protein interactors we are particularly curious about EMB-4. We wonder if Aquarius/EMB-4 might provide new insights into the interface between the nuclear RNAi pathway and the general RNA processing machinery. Our results demonstrate that EMB-4 is an essential factor for piRNA-mediated coTGS in the germline. We then further conclude that Aquarius/EMB-4 is required for the establishment of co-transcriptional gene silencing.Next, we aim to understand the role of Aquarius/EMB-4 on the endogenous transcriptome. We find that genes with high 22G-RNA density in wild-type animals tend to be up-regulated in both h rde-1 and emb-4 mutants. For further analysis, we group all genes into bins of increasing 22G-RNA density and find a number of correlating features.We conclude that HRDE-1 and Aquarius/EMB-4 act together to silence many endogenous 22G-RNA target loci, genes, and transposable elements. Taken together, our results support a model where the RNA helicase Aquarius/EMB-4 is required to provide the co-transcriptional silencing complex access to nascent transcripts undergoing splicing. We conclude that pre-mRNA processing is a natural and powerful barrier to co-transcriptional gene silencing.
